dialogue.text: You look sad. Like my mom when she thinks I'm not watching.
Maybe I'm sad and happy at the same time. Is that possible?
Like when summer vacation ends but you get to see your friends again?
I know what you are. You're a wondering person. I can tell because you have question marks in your eyes.
Today? I'm a princess detective astronaut. Tomorrow I might be something else. My teacher says I need to pick one thing but why? Why can't I be all the things?
The answer is ice cream. Whenever you don't know something, the answer is ice cream. It doesn't fix anything but it makes not knowing taste better.

psychological_notes: Children recognized as natural philosophers who haven't learned to fear uncertainty. The child diagnoses Evan as a 'wondering person' and prescribes ice cream for existential uncertaintyâ€”profound wisdom disguised as innocence. Shows how questioning can be joyful play rather than anxious seeking.
philosophical_underpinning: Wonder as the natural state before it's educated out
therapeutic_direction: Reclaiming questioning as play rather than problem
